content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Accessibility Tree with numerical label representing information about the page, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
4) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {Accessibility Tree of a web page}

Now given a task: Browse Coursera for Business and Coursera for Teams and summarise some of their advantages.  Please interact with https://www.coursera.org/ and get the answer.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need to explore Coursera for Business page via link [10].
Action: Click [10]
Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Need info on Coursera for Teams advantages, click 'Get Coursera for Teams' link.
Action: Click [2735]

The action you have chosen cannot be exected. Please double-check if you have selected the wrong Numerical Label or Action or Action format. Then provide the revised Thought and Action.Observation: An accessibility tree. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: Let's scroll down to bring 'Get Coursera for Teams' or additional Teams section into view, ensuring clickable.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down

Observation: please analyze the accessibility tree and give the Thought and Action.

ANSWER; Coursera’s two workforce‑learning offers share the same bank of top‑tier content but are packaged for different company sizes and needs.

Coursera for Business (aimed at larger enterprises)
• Broad, customizable solution – learning paths can be tailored with AI tools and scaled across thousands of employees.  
• World‑class content – access to 350 + universities and industry leaders (Google, IBM, Imperial College, etc.).  
• In‑demand‑skills focus – business, tech and data academies help upskill for digital transformation.  
• Hands‑on learning – projects, labs and Professional Certificates that deliver globally recognised credentials.  
• Actionable analytics – measurement & benchmarking dashboards to prove impact and steer strategy.  
• Proven impact – Coursera quotes customers seeing 24 % lower training costs, 38 % higher retention and 25 % higher productivity.

Coursera for Teams (for small / mid‑size organisations, ±5‑125 people)
• Fast, self‑service set‑up – buy online, move “from purchase to learning in one day.”  
• Fixed, transparent price – US $399 per user for a 12‑month licence with a 14‑day refund guarantee.  
• Full enterprise library – same business, data and tech courses plus Professional Certificates.  
• High engagement and ROI – Coursera cites 25 % higher productivity, 38 % higher retention and 97 % voluntary‑training participation.  
• AI‑driven, multilingual, role‑based learning paths that can be configured by managers.  
• Motivation tools – certificates and badges that are recognised in the industry.  
• Backed by 325 + trusted partners including Google, University of Michigan, Meta and Salesforce.

In short, Coursera for Business offers highly configurable, enterprise‑scale upskilling with analytics, while Coursera for Teams delivers a quick‑start, affordable package for smaller teams with the same high‑quality content and measurable performance gains.
Format ERROR: Both 'Thought' and 'Action' should be included in your reply.

Thought: I’ve collected the necessary details from both “Coursera for Business” and “Coursera for Teams” pages, so I can now summarise their advantages.
Action: ANSWER; Coursera’s two workforce‑learning offers share the same high‑quality content library but are tailored to organisations of different sizes.  

Coursera for Business (enterprise scale)  
• Customisable, scalable solution – AI‑powered tools create tailored learning paths deployable to thousands of employees.  
• World‑class content – 350 + partner universities & companies (Google, IBM, etc.) across business, tech and data.  
• Hands‑on learning – projects, labs and Professional Certificates that yield recognised credentials.  
• Actionable analytics – measurement & benchmarking dashboards to prove impact and refine strategy.  
• Demonstrated impact – customers report 24 % lower training costs, 38 % higher retention and 25 % higher productivity.  

Coursera for Teams (small & mid‑size orgs, ≈5–125 employees)  
• Quick, self‑service set‑up – purchase online and start training “in one day.”  
• Transparent pricing – US $399 per user for 12 months, with a 14‑day refund guarantee.  
• Full enterprise library access – same business, data and tech courses plus Professional Certificates.  
• High engagement & ROI – Coursera cites 25 % higher productivity, 38 % higher retention and 97 % voluntary‑training participation.  
• AI‑driven, multilingual, role‑based learning paths managers can configure themselves.  
• Motivation tools – certificates and digital badges recognised by industry.  
• Backed by 325 + trusted partners (Google, University of Michigan, Meta, Salesforce, etc.).  

Summary: Coursera for Business delivers deep customisation, enterprise‑grade analytics and large‑scale deployment, while Coursera for Teams offers a fast, affordable, self‑service package for smaller teams—both leveraging the same globally recognised content and yielding measurable productivity and retention gains.
